conc concu abs_rate abs_rateu

``` ::: ::: ::: {#8 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} lst = Vector{Markdown.MD}() M(str::String) = Markdown.parse(str) n = nrow(df) concu = only(unique(df[!, :concu])) abs_rateu = only(unique(df[!, :abs_rateu])) for i in 1:n if i < n conc1 = df[i, :conc] conc2 = df[i+1, :conc] conc_rat = conc2/conc1 abs_rate1 = df[i, :abs_rate] abs_rate2 = df[i+1, :abs_rate] abs_rate_rat = abs_rate2 / abs_rate1 push!(lst, Markdown.parse("From **$conc1** to **$conc2** $concu (**$(conc_rat)x**), absorption rate changes from **$abs_rate1** to **$abs_rate2** $abs_rateu (**$(abs_rate_rat)x**)")) end end display.(lst); plt = data(df) * mapping(:conc, :abs_rate) * visual(ScatterLines) display(draw(plt; figure=(;title = "conc vs abs rate"), axis = (; width = 400, height = 360))) # display(M("This suggests that **rate of absorption is directly proportional to concentration**. This suggests that rate of absorption is directly proportional to concentration. That is:

``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown} \begin{equation} Rate = \mathit{k} \cdot Conc \end{equation} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

This is the hallmark of a first-order process, where the rate depends linearly on the concentration.

``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Question 3 A new antibiotic tablet was developed and administered to a group of volunteers. - 40% of the orally administered dose was excreted unchanged in the feces. - In another study, it was shown that the drug was not excreted in the bile, and that the extraction ratio of the drug by the liver was 70%. - Calculate the bioavailability of this drug in this dosage form. (Assume that no gut wall metabolism exists). **Bioavailability Calculation** Given: - 40% of the orally administered dose is excreted unchanged in feces $$ F_{\text{abs}} = 1 - 0.40 = 0.60 $$ - Hepatic extraction ratio: $$ E_H = 0.70 $$ - No gut wall metabolism **Bioavailability Formula**: $$ F = F_{\text{abs}} \times (1 - E_H) $$ **Substitute the values**: $$ F = 0.60 \times (1 - 0.70) = 0.60 \times 0.30 = 0.18 $$ **Final Answer**: $$ \boxed{F = 0.18 \quad \text{or} \quad 18\%} $$ # Question 4 1. Two membrane characteristics that will increase the rate of absorption of a drug across the membrane are an increase in **surface area** or a decrease in **membrane thickness**. 2. Two drug characteristics that will decrease its rate of absorption across the membrane are a decrease in **molecular size** or an increase in **drug lipophilicity**. 3. Proteins and phospholipids each have both hydrophilic and lipophilic characteristics. This is why they are known as **amphipathic** molecules. 4. If a molecule has a relatively low octanol to water partition coefficient, you would expect its passive diffusion across a membrane to be **slow**. 5. The anatomical feature of the small intestine that most enhances its surface area is the **villi**. 6. The barrier to absorption in the small intestine is the **mucus layer**. 7. The cell type with the "leakiest" tight junction is the **brain capillary**. 8. When a molecule crosses through the cell, it is considered to go through the **transcellular** route across the barrier. 9. When a molecule goes between cells, it is considered to go through the **paracellular** route across the barrier. # Question 5 | No. | Description | Answer | |-----|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------| | 1 | Can cause an increase in membrane viscosity | i.
